Protesters storm flow stations

In the northern city of Kano, Muslims protested the Yelwa killings. The protests soon turned violent, and on May 11 and 12, mobs in Kano killed more than 200 Christian residents. Security forces killed dozens of civilians, most of them Muslims, as they intervened to supposedy quell the riots on the two days. By early July, 228 people had been arrested in connection with the riots, 45 charged, and 102 released.

Christian groups attack Muslim residents in Yelwa, contininuing ongoing religious based violence in the area. Soldiers eventually dispersed the attackers at noon on the second day. Human Rights Watch estimates that at least 700 people were killed in the violence over the two days. Between 200 and 300 Muslim women and children were abducted and released in the days or weeks that followed, a number of them having been repeatedly raped by their captors, and tens of thousands of people fled to other places in Plateau state or in neighbouring areas.

Muslim militia allegedly attacked Kawo village near Yelwa, killing one Christian. This incident allegedly sparked one of the most intense attack by Christians on Muslims in Yelwa town: about 700 Muslims will be killed in two days of violence.

Christians killed at least 40 Muslims in revenge for the attack on Yelwa church two days earlier.

At least 78 Christians were killed in an attack on Yelwa by a suspected Fulani Muslim militia, including 48 in a Church compound known as COCIN no. 1 on the road leading to Langtang south. The attack began a series of tit-for-tat attacks between the two groups over the next two months.

Suspected Fulani militia attacked the Christian villages of Tabat, Timshat, Tukung, Zamwe, and Tumbi, on the same day as a similar attack perpetrated in Yelwa that killed at least 78 people. Overall fatalities in these villages are unknown but 10 people were reported to have been killed in Timshat.

Fulani militia angry over cattle theft allegedly killed Christians in several villages in Langtang South on 21 or 22 February. Christians from Langtang South then killed at least nine people in predominantly Muslim Yamini, also burning several surrounding villages, including Lakushi, Sabon Layi and Ajikamai.

Nigerian police said on Thursday that vigilante groups had shot dead seven Islamic fundamentalists belonging to the group which staged an abortive uprising in the northeast of the country last month as they attempted to cross the border to Cameroon. The militants were killed on Monday night in the village of Damboa near the Cameroon border. A group of 10 Islamic militants entered the village and shot dead one of the vigilantes who challenged them. Seven of the militants were then killed and the other three were arrested

Nigeria declared Saturday it had put down an armed uprising by an Islamic movement seeking to create a Muslim state. Two police officers and at least six of the militants died in five days of clashes in three towns in predominantly Islamic Yobe state, including the capital, Damaturu. The battles sent scores of families fleeing the targeted communities of Geidam and Kanamma.
